title: 113_hr4937
content: The Act titled "Protection Against Wasteful Spending Act of 2014" requires recommendations on wasteful and excessive spending. The "Protection Against Wasteful Spending Act of 2014" mandates the implementation of recommendations from inspector general reports on wasteful spending, with exceptions for recommendations that violate existing laws. If a recommendation conflicts with a law, the agency head must propose a legal change to Congress. The "Protection Against Wasteful Spending Act of 2014" requires agencies to submit a report to Congress on the progress of implementing IG report recommendations, timeframes for completion, identification of wasteful spending, savings from recommendations, and reasons for not implementing recommendations earlier. The "Protection Against Wasteful Spending Act of 2014" mandates agencies to provide Congress with updated reports on the implementation of IG report recommendations annually, starting 13 months after the initial report submission. SEC. 3. FAILURE TO IMPLEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS. Any agency failing to implement a recommendation from an IG report in a timely manner may not use funds for convention or seminar attendance, travel by politically-appointed officials, bonuses, or salary increases. If the agency still fails to implement the recommendation after 60 days, 50 percent of the funds will be credited to the Highway Trust Fund. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allocates funds for State water pollution control revolving funds under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The term "timely manner" is defined as 30 percent completion of IG report recommendations. The Internal Revenue Code allocates funds for State water pollution control revolving funds under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. "Timely manner" means completing 30 percent of IG report recommendations in the first year and 70 percent in the second year. SEC. 4. USE OF SAVINGS. Savings from IG report recommendations will be split: 50% to Highway Trust Fund, 50% to EPA for water pollution control grants. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "agency" refers to the meaning in section 551 of title 5, United States Code, and "politically-appointed official" is any Federal Government employee not paid under the General Schedule and appointed by the President with Senate consent.
